title: 2 MaineDOT workers killed on the job after driver blows through stop sign, police say
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Local News James Brown, 60, and Dwayne Campbell, 51, were struck by a minivan after the driver failed to stop at a posted stop sign, according to Maine State Police.
By Carson Lyle January 13, 2026 | 6:07 PM 1 minute to read Two Maine Department of Transportation workers were killed Tuesday after a minivan collided with them in a posted work zone, officials said.

title: Why did Morgan Geekie leave Saturday’s game vs. the Rangers? His wife went into labor at TD Garden.
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Boston Bruins "Obviously it’s been on my mind for a while because it’s very unpredictable.
" Morgan Geekie is looking to get back on the scoresheet with Boston.
AP Photo/Ethan Swope By Conor Ryan January 13, 2026 | 5:16 PM 2 minutes to read Saturday was a hectic afternoon for Morgan Geekie and his family.

title: Patriots RB TreVeyon Henderson among 6 finalists for NFL’s fan-voted Rookie of the Year award
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: New England Patriots Henderson is on the ballot for the Pepsi Zero Sugar Rookie of the Year.
TreVeyon Henderson.
Winslow Townson/AP Images for Panini Patriots running back TreVeyon Henderson is one of six finalists for the Pepsi Zero Sugar Rookie of the Year award, the NFL announced Tuesday.

title: UNO Pizzeria & Grill closes three longtime Massachusetts locations
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Food News The Dedham, Revere, and Braintree restaurants shut their doors after more than three decades, citing rising costs and shifting dining habits.
A large Chicago Classic deep dish pizza from Uno Pizzeria and Grille in Braintree, Mass.

Globe staff photo by John Tlumacki UNO Pizzeria & Grill has closed its locations in Dedham, Revere, and Braintree after more than three decades in business, according to announcements posted to the restaurant’s Facebook page.

title: Plans to redevelop Alewife’s MBTA garage fall apart
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Local News The MBTA is scrapping a proposal to remake the site, leaving the concrete garage a persistent headache for riders and residents.
An aerial view of the Alewife garage in Cambridge.
Kayla Bartkowski for The Boston Globe ShareSend this article to your social connections.

title: Report: Chargers fire offensive coordinator, OL coach after wild-card loss to Patriots
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: New England Patriots The Chargers scored 3 points against New England, the lowest total in the wild-card round.
Justin Herbert was sacked six times during Sunday's playoff loss to the Patriots.

title: Video shows driver sideswiping houses, falling from car window in Everett
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Local News “You don’t expect that you could be part of a car crash when you are sleeping inside your own home,” one neighbor said.
The aftermath of a stunning single-car crash in Everett Sunday morning.

Eliza Brennan-Pratt/Courtesy By Abby Patkin January 13, 2026 | 3:55 PM 1 minute to read A driver in Everett tumbled from their car window Sunday morning after crashing in a residential neighborhood, an eyebrow-raising wreck caught on home surveillance footage.

title: ‘There’s more of a story to tell’: 7 takeaways from Karen Read’s first in-depth interview after acquittal
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Local News Read has mostly kept mum about the sensational murder case that rocked Greater Boston.
Until now.
Karen Read leaves Norfolk Superior Court after the opening day of her first trial, Monday, April 29, 2024, in Dedham, Mass.

title: After Warren’s speech assailing Trump, he called her. Here’s what they discussed.
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Politics Sen.
Elizabeth Warren and President Donald Trump are fierce opponents, but they do have a couple of shared policy goals.

title: Bill Belichick breaks down what went right for the Patriots and wrong for the Chargers
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: New England Patriots The Chargers fell behind early and couldn't muster enough offense to match the Patriots.

Bill Belichick AP Photo/Chris Seward Bill Belichick had a hunch that things would be difficult for the Chargers if they had to play from behind against the Patriots during last Sunday’s NFL wild-card matchup.

He mentioned the Chargers’ offensive line woes after losing tackles Rashawn Slater and Joe Alt to season-ending injuries, along with Justin Herbert’s injured hands as reasons why a Los Angeles comeback would have been difficult.
